body: If we plan a breaking change it is better make it before RTM.

scripts to summarize the differences
--------
```powershell
function from_begin { begin { @{"simple function Begin block" = $input.GetType().FullName} } }
function from_process { process { @{"simple function Process block" = $input.GetType().FullName} } }
function from_end { end { @{"simple function End block" = $input.GetType().FullName} } }


function cmdlet_from_begin { [cmdletbinding()]param() begin { @{"script cmdlet Begin block" = $input.GetType().FullName} } }
function cmdlet_from_process { [cmdletbinding()]param() process { @{"script cmdlet Process block" = $input.GetType().FullName} } }
function cmdlet_from_end { [cmdletbinding()]param() end { @{"script cmdlet End block: {0}" = $input.GetType().FullName} } }

. { from_begin; from_process; from_end; cmdlet_from_begin; cmdlet_from_process; cmdlet_from_end }
```
resutls on PowerShell V2
-------
```none
Name                           Value
----                           -----
simple function Begin block    System.Collections.ArrayList+ArrayListEnumeratorSimple
simple function Process block  System.Collections.ArrayList+ArrayListEnumeratorSimple
simple function End block      System.Collections.ArrayList+ArrayListEnumeratorSimple
script cmdlet Begin block      System.Collections.ArrayList+ArrayListEnumeratorSimple
script cmdlet Process block    System.Collections.ArrayList+ArrayListEnumeratorSimple
script cmdlet End block: {0}   System.Array+SZArrayEnumerator
```
results on PowerShell V3 and newer
-------
```none
Name                           Value
----                           -----
simple function Begin block    System.Collections.ArrayList+ArrayListEnumeratorSimple
simple function Process block  System.Collections.ArrayList+ArrayListEnumeratorSimple
simple function End block      System.Collections.ArrayList+ArrayListEnumeratorSimple
script cmdlet Begin block      System.Collections.ArrayList
script cmdlet Process block    System.Collections.ArrayList
script cmdlet End block: {0}   System.Object[]
```
Some context I found from an early email:
------
> `$input` is documented in the language specification as being an enumerator (`IEnumerator`), and that’s how it’s implemented in V2.
> V3 unintentionally changed the type of `$input` in a script cmdlet to an `ArrayList` or `Array` (depending on when you ask).
>
> I thought it was a relatively safe fix to make because the use of `$input` in a script cmdlet should be uncommon because it’s usually better to use a parameter that has `ValueFromPipeline` or to just use `$_`.
>
> It turns out I was wrong.  We have reverted the change and the fix is scheduled to be delivered as part of the ZDP for the Windows 10 Anniversary Update.
>
> That does leave us in this weird place – scripts that target V2 and later might not work correctly if they use `$input` in a script cmdlet.
> It also means the `$input` is different in a script cmdlet and ordinary function.
>
> So we may revisit this in the future, but if we do, we’ll do a better job notifying people about the change in behavior.
@PowerShell/powershell-committee This issue is ready to be reviewed again.
@PowerShell/powershell-committee reviewed this and agreed it doesn't make sense to make this change back to v2 behavior at this time since v3+ users would be broken
